description: From Middle English rent, rente, from Old French rente and Medieval Latin renta, both from Vulgar Latin *rendere, from Latin reddere, present active infinitive of reddō.

entries.meaning: A payment made by a tenant at intervals in order to occupy a property.
examples: I am asking £100 a week rent.

entries.meaning: A similar payment for the use of a product, equipment or a service.
(economics) A profit from possession of a valuable right, as a restricted license to engage in a trade or business.
examples: A New York city taxicab license earns more than $10,000 a year in rent.

entries.meaning: An object for which rent is charged or paid.

verbs.description: rent (third-person singular simple present rents, present participle renting, simple past and past participle rented)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To occupy premises in exchange for rent.
examples: I rented a house from my friend's parents for a year.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To grant occupation in return for rent.
examples: We rented our house to our son's friend for a year.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To obtain or have temporary possession of an object (e.g. a movie) in exchange for money.
(intransitive) To be leased or let for rent.
examples: The house rents for five hundred dollars a month.

description: From Middle English renten (“to tear”). Variant form of renden.

adjectives.description: rent (comparative more rent, superlative most rent)

entries.meaning: That has been torn or rent; ripped; torn.
A tear or rip in some surface.

examples: […]  the White House was considering sending Vice President Humphrey to Cairo to patch up the many rents in U.S.—Egyptian relations.

entries.meaning: simple past tense and past participle of rend
